entry.title: New Portfolio Layout, Woo~
entry.content:
Hurray!

I have to say it's a pretty huge improvement over the old layout I've had for over a year now, and it's due to the fact that I can do a ton of front-end work at my new job. I can't believe how much I've learned over the past four months, including but not limited to standard stuff like jQuery that I have always wanted to practice but hadn't found the time for.

This particular layout makes use of a new CSS trick that I learned, and really like -- a way to resize the "top" div of a website so that it always fits in the space above the fold, no matter the size. All you need is a container div, and inside that two more divs: one for the area above the fold (the "landing"), and one for your "main" information.

The CSS looks like:

html,body {
margin:0px auto;
height:100%;
}

div#container {
min-width:100%;
height:100%;
}

div#landing {
width:100%;
height:100%;
background: #5d5d5d url("../images/header_bg.jpg") center center no-repeat;
background-size:cover;
}

div#main {
background-color:#eeeee2;
}

And the HTML should be like:
<body>
 
    top part of page
  
 
    the rest of the page
  
</body>

How exciting.

entry.title: A Suggestion for Padmapper
entry.content:
It would be nice if, alongside the other constraints for searching, you could input locations -- i.e. "Downtown Seattle," "University District." Then, along with the Walkscore and Street View of an individual listing, you could see how long it takes to get to these locations via nearby bus lines. I'm finding myself making sure that locations on Padmapper are near bus lines by typing in addresses into Google Maps, and I did this too when trying to find a place to live in San Francisco this summer.

Actually, even listing "nearby bus lines" would just be helpful. (Though not as helpful if you're not familiar with a city's public transportation, as was the case with me, SF, and BART.)

That being said, using Padmapper thus far instead of just scrolling text ads on Craigslist has made apartment hunting a little more fun. But it may be because I have a fondness of maps in general.
